question: Question_03_(c)
statement:
What does ``Cantor's Diagonalization Argument'' prove? (You don't have
to describe the proof itself - just what it proves.)
sols:
Cantor's Diagonalization Argument is used to prove that the set of all
real numbers is uncountable.

More precisely, it says that if you claim that the set of all real
numbers is actually countable, that is, you have a bijection between all
real number and the natural numbers, then he would be able to exhibit
you a real number (using the diagonalization argument) that is
\textbf{not} listed by your bijection. This means it is a contradiction
to assume that such a bijection could exist and hence the real numbers
are uncountable.
hints:
Here the question simply aims at having you write a very short paragraph
about what Cantor's argument proves, no need for complicated math, just
a sentence or two that explains what he proved with that argument. (Yes,
that's math too :) )
